title: Open air breastfeed and marching lawyers on third day of XR protests
text:
Extinction Rebellion protesters are kicking off day three of the demonstration (Picture: AP/ PA)

It’s day three of London’s Extinction Rebellion and the environmental protests are not about to start slowing down.

Activists are currently camping out in the capital as part of a two-week peaceful demonstration that is being replicated in more than 60 cities across the world.

The Met Police confirmed they have made 471 XR arrests so far this week, with protesters gluing themselves to government buildings and lying under vehicles in the street.

Today’s protests will see main roads around Westminster, Trafalgar Square, Parliament Square, Whitehall and Strand blockaded by activists once again.

The demonstrations will continue to target governmental buildings, with protesters camped outside Downing Street, the Home Office and Department of Transport.

The protest will be going on for two weeks (Picture: Reuters)

Police said 471 people have been arrested in the protests (Picture: AP)

Many activists are camping out in the capital (Picture: AP)

Activists resist police movement (Picture: Rex Features)

Rows of tents are waiting for Boris Johnson outside Downing Street (Picture: PA)

Other events during the day will include a ‘mass mothers’ nurse-in’ at a Westminster road blockade, lawyers marching by the Royal Courts of Justice and a cricket game in Parliament Square.

Meanwhile XR Youth are expected to gather outside the Department of Education to demand that the school curricula is changed to include climate change issues.

Mum burned by hot water bottle that exploded after she put it down her trousers

There will also be a ‘parents meeting’ and leaf printing in the afternoon on The Mall, St James Park, held by XR Families.

A funeral hearse will block the entrance to the XR ‘Burning Earth’ site in Trafalgar Square for the third day in a row.

Yesterday saw protesters glue themselves to the entrance of the Department of Transport, dance in the streets of Whitehall and lie under a parked lorry in Westminster.

In the afternoon, Met Police began to clear barricaded bridges and ushered activists from Parliament Square to the ‘pedestrianised area’ of Trafalgar Square.

They warned that anyone refusing to move was ‘liable to arrest and prosecution’.

There were 319 people arrested on Monday and 152 taken into custody on Tuesday, although Scotland Yard did not provide further details on what the protesters had been accused of.

Updated arrest figures would be published later, the Met said.
